docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said merging the ProMedica Health System and St. Luke’s Hospital would “substantially lessen competition” around Toledo, leading to higher prices.

headline.seo: In Ohio, F.T.C. Bans ProMedica-St. Luke’s Merger
headline.main: Regulator Orders Hospitals to Undo a Merger in Ohio
headline.print_headline: Regulator Orders Hospitals To Undo a Merger in Ohio

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission blocks the merger of Ohio hospitals ProMedica Health System and St Luke's Hospital, saying that it would substantially lessen competition and allow the hospitals to charge higher prices; ruling is seen as a sign that regulators may reject the consolidation of medical providers promoted by the new health care legislation as a violation of antitrust law.
docs.snippet: The Federal Trade Commission said merging the ProMedica Health System and St. Luke’s Hospital would “substantially lessen competition” around Toledo, leading to higher prices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wall Street, which buys and sells all types of exotic securities, has found a limit to its financial innovation. It can't trade derivatives tied to the 2012 election. On Monday, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission rejected a plan for so-called political event contracts, wary that mixing politics and trading would create a dangerous cocktail. The agency ruled, in part, that such trading amounts to gambling - and that it could unduly influence election results.

headline.main: Panel Rejects Proposal to Allow Election-Related Trading

docs.abstract: Commodity Futures Trading Commission rejects North American Derivatives Exchange's plan for so-called political event contracts; says the trading plan amounts to gambling and could unduly affect 2012 Congressional and presidential election results. Photo (M)
docs.snippet: Wall Street, which buys and sells all types of exotic securities, has found a limit to its financial innovation. It can't trade derivatives tied to the 2012 election.     On Monday, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission rejected a plan for...

docs.lead_paragraph: I was so excited for what lay ahead, I nearly forgot to wave goodbye to my parents. Armed with a college diploma, my first job offer, a one-way ticket to Paris and a new pair of heels, I was ready to take on anything. Little did I know, I would be back in New York seven short months later. But my parents would not be taking pictures at the airport or chatting about my future plans. I would be in a wheelchair, too weak to walk. In Paris, the doctors had struggled to make sense of my symptoms - anemia, fatigue and persistent infections. They ran test after test - I was even hospitalized for a week - but the results were inconclusive. I was just 22, but the doctors released me with a diagnosis of ''burnout syndrome'' and orders to rest for a month.
docs.abstract: Suleika Jaouad essay shares the difficulties of undergoing cancer treatment as a young adult, saying that her journey to date has made her realize that age is an inextricable component of how cancer is experienced. Photo (M)

byline.original: By SULEIKA JAOUAD; Suleika Jaouad is a 23-year-old writer from Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Her column, ''Life, Interrupted,'' chronicling her experiences as a young adult with cancer, will appear weekly at nytimes.com/well
